title: Geth Page Fault - manual restart required
body:
#### System information

Geth version: 1.11.1-stable
CL client & version: teku 23.2.0
OS & Version: Ubuntu 22.04.2 LTS (GNU/Linux 5.15.0-67-generic x86_64)

It seems like geth suffered a page fault for some reason, and then just... stopped. Not that service stopped, just geth stopped and occasionally output: `WARN [03-04|00:46:09.423] Beacon client online, but no consensus updates received in a while. Please fix your beacon client to follow the chain!`
Restarting the service fixed things and it re-sync-ed itself, but perhaps it should have tried to do that itself?


> Not that service stopped, just geth stopped and occasionally output: WARN [03-04|00:46:09.423] Beacon client online, but no consensus updates received in a while. Please fix your beacon client to follow the chain!


Did you mean Geth is still alive but print this log periodically? It means Geth never receives signal from the associated consensus layer client.


If Geth is crashed, please provide the log where the crash starts.
Yes, you are correct: "Geth is still alive but print this log periodically"

Please fix your consensus client then(sorry for mis-clicking bottom)

Re page fault, I don't think we can do anything here.

The consensus client then did this:
```
Mar  4 00:45:20 teku[1637]: 2023-03-04 00:45:20.631 WARN  - #033[33mExecution Client request timed out. Make sure the Execution Client is online and in sync.#033[0m
Mar  4 00:45:20 teku[1637]: 2023-03-04 00:45:20.631 ERROR - Unable to import block: Execution Client returned an error: tech.pegasys.teku.ethereum.executionlayer.InvalidRemoteResponseException: Invalid remote response from the execution client: TimeoutException
```
So, both thought the other weren't working, however it was geth that had stopped doing anything.
Perhaps you can check (1) the RPC endpoint is configured correctly `--authrpc.addr`, `--authrpc.port` (2) ensure the jwt token is configured correctly `--authrpc.jwtsecret`

Yeah, my validators have been running for years (and months post-merge) just fine.
Geth suffered a page fault and then stopped doing things. I don't know what else to tell you.

Well, geth was alive, but apparently the CL could not communicate with it. Seems like something broke related to RPC. That trace you posted is not a golang-trace, it's an actual kernel-dump. So whatever happened, might be somewhat outside of geth's domain. 

I don't think there's anything we can do here. Feel free to reopen if it happens again.
